author: Special Correspondent
text:
Three CPI (M)-affiliated organisations came together on Wednesday to organise a protest against recent anti-farmer decisions by private banks and financial institutions in the State.

The Tamil Nadu Farmers’ Association, Bank Employees Federation of India and Democratic Youth Federation of India initially planned their protest in front of a branch of Kotak Mahindra Bank on T. Nagar’s Venkatanarayana Road.

The 60-odd individuals were denied access to the proposed venue by the police and were forced to protest outside the nearby Natesan Park.

Kotak Mahindra was chosen because its Thanjavur branch on March 4 tried to recover a farmer’s tractor for defaulting. This led to G. Balan, the farmer, being assaulted by policemen.

However, the protesters were keen to point out other instances. “There has been no FIR against those who assaulted Balan. The men who insulted Alagar were former policemen. The government could have at least cautioned their staff from working for such companies,” said P. Shanmugam, general secretary of TNFA.

Alagar committed suicide on March 11 after representatives of Cholamandalam Finance seized his tractor.

Shanmugam also criticised the various tactics of private players. “Kotak Mahindra obtained an ex-parte order against Balan. The Inspector slapped him when he demanded to see the order,” he said.

Shanmugam pointed out that the response has been disproportionate: Balan had already paid Rs. 4.11 lakhs after borrowing Rs. 3.8 lakh and had only two instalments left; Alagar paid Rs. 5 lakh after borrowing Rs. 7 lakh.
title: ‘Protest against anti-farmer financial institutions’
